audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker greeting a biology class and introducing lesson two on the "respiratory system," specifying the "mouth, pharynx, and larynx." He notes they've discussed these topics in the digestive system unit and will approach them in a different context. He then highlights key points, including "mouth, cleft palate, pharynx and larynx" and calls them "self-explanatory." He says they will "jump right in" and talk about it in a "breathing context," then mentions "nose to mouth."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining the connection between the nose and mouth. He notes that they are linked by "the nasopharynx and oropharynx" at the back of the throat, allowing one to "breathe through your nose or your mouth" to the same place, establishing a connection. He speaks in an informative, conversational tone.

The clip starts with a male speaker describing how a chain can be put through the nose and pulled out of the mouth, suggesting it shows the connection between the two. He then mentions using headphones to create a speaker, implying it utilizes this connection. He suggests people check out related videos. The speaker describes how they supposedly prove "that your nose and your mouth are connected" and that "they both lead to the same place which is your throat."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining the role of the mouth in various functions like eating, drinking, and speaking, characterizing the latter as a respiratory system role. He then introduces the concept of mouth breathing as an alternative to nasal breathing in cases of obstruction. His speaking tone is informative and clear.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing the benefits of breathing through the nose rather than the mouth, especially for filtering and warming air before it enters the lungs. The speaker explains that mouth breathing can be useful during physical activity or when there's a blockage, but is not recommended for regular life, particularly in cold climates.

The audio begins with a male speaker describing a cleft palate and its impact on voice, mentioning it is easily repaired with surgery. The speaker then defines the pharynx and its role in the digestive and respiratory systems as well as air filtration.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing the pharynx, dividing it into sections like the nasopharynx, oropharynx, and laryngopharynx, mentioning its function of connecting the nose and mouth to the lower respiratory system and enabling eating and breathing at the same time. He describes the different types of pharynx and references a picture showing the nasopharynx, oropharynx, laryngopharynx, larynx, and trachea, also explaining the role of the epiglottis in blocking the windpipe during eating. His tone is informative and educational throughout.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker discussing the epiglottis, explaining its function in preventing food from entering the windpipe and its role in breathing and speaking. He notes the difficulty of speaking and eating simultaneously due to the epiglottis needing to open and close at the same time. His tone is informative and somewhat educational.

The clip starts with a male speaker describing "epiglottitis" as an inflammation that can cause breathing difficulties. He suggests watching videos to understand the epiglottis's function, referring to a "digestion unit." The clip concludes with a faint, unidentifiable sound effect.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing the larynx as the voice box, located in the neck, mentioning the Adam's apple and cartilage. He indicates its involvement in breathing, sound production, and protection of the trachea, further elaborating on its role in housing the vocal cords and manipulating pitch and volume for phonation.

The audio begins with a single male speaker discussing how to manipulate voice pitch and volume, associating phonation with speaking. He mentions the use of microphones and helium to alter voice and shows a picture of the larynx, describing the cartilage protecting the vocal cords, which tighten or widen to control vocal pitch. He suggests checking out videos of people altering their voice pitch and notes the importance of knowing different gases that can cause these effects, mentioning helium, sulfur hexafluoride, and xenon. A distinct musical note is heard at the very end of the clip.

The audio features a single male speaker, who begins by assigning a task, instructing the listener to research how the larynx works on a website. He maintains a neutral and informative tone, outlining the task, expressing confidence in the listener's ability, and offering assistance. The speaker then concludes the message by promising to see the listener in the next lesson.
